title: 'I guess I'm the Meryl Streep of generals': Former Secretary of Defense Jim Mattis jokes after Trump's criticism
text:
CLOSE A meeting on Turkey and Syria resulted in Democrats walking out after they claimed the president was “demeaning” toward Pelosi, and had a “meltdown.” USA TODAY

WASHINGTON – Former Secretary of Defense Jim Mattis had a witty response to reports that President Donald Trump called him “the world’s most overrated general” during a heated meeting with congressional Democrats Wednesday.

“I do stand before you as was noted here, really, having achieved greatness,” Mattis begins, speaking at the Al Smith Memorial Foundation dinner on Thursday, prompting laughter. “I mean, I’m not just an overrated general, I am the greatest, the world’s most overrated general.”

“I'm honored to be considered that by Donald Trump because he also called Meryl Streep an overrated actress. So, I guess I'm the Meryl Streep of generals, and frankly, that sounds pretty good to me," he continues.

“You do have to admit, that between me, and Meryl at least we’ve had some victories,” Mattis quipped.

The President called Streep "one of the most over-rated actresses in Hollywood" after she criticized him during a speech at the Golden Globes shortly after the 2016 elections.

Streep is the most nominated actor in the history of the Academy Awards.

"I’m not just an overrated general. I’m the most overrated general," Mattis says. "I'm honored to be considered that by Donald Trump because he also called Meryl Streep an overrated actress. So I guess I'm the Meryl Streep of generals, and frankly that sounds pretty good to me." pic.twitter.com/Hzpe5lUeje — NBC News (@NBCNews) October 18, 2019

He jokingly thanked Minority Leader Senator Chuck Schumer for bringing his name up in the “a rather contentious meeting in Washington” between the White House and congressional Democrats that focused on the situation in Syria that resulted in Democrats storming out.

More: The Syria-Turkey cease-fire, quid pro quo talk and death of Elijah Cummings: Catch up on a busy Thursday in politics

During Wednesday’s tense showdown, Schumer referenced Mattis's appearance on "Meet the Press," where he warned "ISIS will resurge" if there is no U.S. pressure in the region.

President Trump’s own former Secretary of Defense Mattis has said ISIS will resurge.



I pushed the president on this yesterday. Mattis is respected here in Washington.



But instead of sharing any plan, the president just tried to claim Mattis ‘the world’s most overrated General.’ pic.twitter.com/dXB5TNcpHX — Chuck Schumer (@SenSchumer) October 17, 2019

Mattis resigned last year after he and Trump butted heads over removing U.S. troops from Syria at the time.

“Like you, I have said from the beginning that the armed forces of the United States should not be the policeman of the world,” Mattis wrote to Trump last December. “Instead, we must use all the tools of American power to provide for the common defense, including providing effective leadership to our alliances.”
